Authors:
James Michel Tchotet Tchoumi, Martin Petrus Albertus
Coetzee, Mario rajchenberg, Jolanda Roux
Title:
Poroid Hymenochaetaceae associated with trees showing
wood-rot symptoms in the Garden Route National Park of South Africa
Keywords:
Biodiversity, indigenous forests, wood-rot fungi, 4 new
taxa
Abstract:
The poroid Hymenochaetaceae associated with wood-rots of
trees in three timber-harvesting compartments of the Garden Route
National Park (GRNP), South Africa, were investigated using phylogenetic
analyses of ITS and LSU sequences and the morphology of basidiomes.
Results revealed the presence of ten species belonging to five genera.
Six of them represented known species, while four are proposed as new
taxa. The newly proposed species are Fomitiporia tsitsikamensis,
Fulvifomes elaeodendri, Fuscoporia pulviniformis and Phellinus
guttiformis spp. novs. Fomitiporia tsitsikamensis sp. nov. was recovered
from dead standing Olea capensis subsp. macrocarpa and living Apodytes
dimidiata subsp. dimidiata. It is characterised by perennial, solitary
or few basidiomes growing together that are resupinate to
pseudo-pileate, a dimitic hyphal system, dextrinoid, subglobose to
globose basidiospores and acuminate to ventricose setae. Fulvifomes
elaeodendri sp. nov. was found exclusively on living trees of
Elaeodendron croceum and is distinguished by perennial, solitary (rarely
two together), broadly attached or semi-circular to dimidiate,
applanate, triquetrous up to ungulate basidiomes, dimitic hyphal system
and broadly ellipsoid to ellipsoid, to almost subglobose basidiospores.
Phellinus guttiformis sp. nov. is characterised by perennial, resupinate
to pseudo-pileate, drop-shaped or hoof-shaped and pendant basidiomes,
dimitic hyphal system, subulate, acuminate to slightly ventricose setae
and broadly ellipsoid, subglobose to globose basidiospores. It was found
fruiting on branches and trunks of Psydrax obovata subsp. obovata and O.
capensis subsp. capensis. Basidiospores were not found for all specimens
examined for Fuscopora pulviniformis. However, its description as a new
species was supported by other distinctive morphological traits, such as
its annual to perennial, resupinate to pulvinate basidiomes with
well-developed margins and its lanceolate, straight hymenial setae.
Isolates representing this species also formed a well-resolved and
strongly supported monophyletic clade based on two combined gene
regions. It was found fruiting on dead standing O. capensis subsp.
capensis, living Psydrax obovata subsp. obovata, and stumps of Cunonia
capensis.
